repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Goal: Make `nvim_open_win` and `nvim_win_set_config` support opening splits, and moving floating windows into splits.

Changes to `FloatConfig`:
- The `win` prop is now also used to determine which window should be split
  - Zero should split the current window, non-zero should split a specific window, and nil should create a top-level split.
  - A side-affect of this is that split windows can now be moved with `nvim_win_set_config`.
- The `relative` prop being set to an empty string now registers as `kFloatRelativeNone` instead of being ignored.
- Added `vertical` and `split` props for controlling split position

Additionally, `win_split_ins` now returns the `win_T*` pointer to the newly created window on success, and `NULL` on failure, as it can initialize windows and it is useful (required for this PR) to have a pointer to the new window after creating it.

TODO:
- [x] Tests
- [x] Docs
- [x] Remove hacks
- [x] Add `vertical` boolean prop <strike>or `direction` string prop</strike> to win configs
- [x] Add `belowright` boolean prop to win configs
- [x] Validation for updated win configs
- [x] Handle case of window already being a normal window
- [x] Fix: Breaks when splitting the current window (sometimes?)
- [x] Create `split` prop, remove `rightbelow` prop
- [x] Rename `FloatConfig` to `WinConfig`
- [ ] Update `nvim_win_get_config`
- [x] Non-floats should use `relative=nil`, not `relative=""`
- [x] Apply width / height props to created splits
- [ ] More tests
  - [ ] Opening windows in non-current tabpage
  - [ ] Moving windows to other tabpages

<details>
<summary>video demo (float to split)</summary>

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38540736/edaac4b2-1fae-4367-8ee8-997b5d668f5c

</details>

<details>
<summary>Moving a split window to another location</summary>

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/assets/38540736/bc8df07a-01d3-4c90-9fee-cdc9a0aafab0

</details>

fixes #14315 (maybe)

comment_data.body: Should I create a `win_new_split` function instead of exposing these directly?
Any reason not to allow omitting `relative` (that was always what I assumed we'd do since we introduced `nvim_open_win`)?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3093,13 +3109,14 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
       • {config}  Map defining the window configuration. Keys:
                   • relative: Sets the window layout to "floating", placed at
                     (row,col) coordinates relative to:
+                    • "" Non-floating

comment_data.body: No, not particularly, I didn't think that through much. Should omitting `relative` resolve to a split window, the same as `relative=""`?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3093,13 +3109,14 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
       • {config}  Map defining the window configuration. Keys:
                   • relative: Sets the window layout to "floating", placed at
                     (row,col) coordinates relative to:
+                    • "" Non-floating

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
                  • win: |window-ID| window to split, or relative window when creating a float (relative="win").
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3093,13 +3109,14 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
       • {config}  Map defining the window configuration. Keys:
                   • relative: Sets the window layout to "floating", placed at
                     (row,col) coordinates relative to:
+                    • "" Non-floating
                     • "editor" The global editor grid
                     • "win" Window given by the `win` field, or current
                       window.
                     • "cursor" Cursor position in current window.
                     • "mouse" Mouse position
 
-                  • win: |window-ID| for relative="win".
+                  • win: |window-ID| for relative="win" or relative="".

comment_data.body:
should this be a `split: 'aboveleft' | 'belowright' | 'topleft' | 'botright'` param similar to `nvim_parse_cmd` ?

I would guess that it makes sense for `nvim_open_win` to normally behave according to the user's 'splitright' and related options, unless explicitly overridden. Because the inverse would make life difficult for plugins that _want_ to respect the user's options.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3195,6 +3212,11 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
                   • fixed: If true when anchor is NW or SW, the float window
                     would be kept fixed even if the window would be truncated.
                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body: I thought about that, definitely could do that if that's preferred. The reason why I ended up with two properties was so that omitting one is possible (and to mirror `splitright`/`splitbelow` options). I somewhat prefer the current implementation, but I don't have strong feelings about it and I definitely understand the appeal of minimizing the number of new properties. Happy to make the change if you want :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3195,6 +3212,11 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
                   • fixed: If true when anchor is NW or SW, the float window
                     would be kept fixed even if the window would be truncated.
                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body:
I don't think `split` would eliminate the need for `vertical`. Rather it avoids the need for other, new options in the future. But I haven't thought through all the permutations so I am not certain if it's necessary. 

Currently my reasoning is:

- As a user, a `split` enum option as described above seems potentially more intuitive than a single `belowright` boolean.
- Matching the existing `nvim_parse_cmd` interface seems like a safe choice.

                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body:
> Should omitting `relative` resolve to a split window, the same as `relative=""`?

Yes. `relative` always was meant to indicate "this is a float". So if not given then it's not a float. I'd also say we _shouldn't_ support `relative=""`. "Relative" is only for floats.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3093,13 +3109,14 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
       • {config}  Map defining the window configuration. Keys:
                   • relative: Sets the window layout to "floating", placed at
                     (row,col) coordinates relative to:
+                    • "" Non-floating

comment_data.body:
Why would vertical still be needed if `split` existed? Wouldn't `topleft` be the same as `vertical=true, belowright=false`, `botright` => `vertical=true, belowright=true`, etc.?

Otherwise that's solid reasoning, I'll update the option to use an enum (probably tomorrow, I'm attempting to fix the tabpage issues atm).

+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body:
> Wouldn't `topleft` be the same as `vertical=true, belowright=false`, `botright` => `vertical=true, belowright=true`, etc.?

Presumably the same reason that `:vertical` command exists :) Can always drop the `vertical` param for now and add it later if needed.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3195,6 +3212,11 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
                   • fixed: If true when anchor is NW or SW, the float window
                     would be kept fixed even if the window would be truncated.
                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body: Ah, so `vertical=true` would essentially be the same as `topleft`, and `vertical=false` would be equivalent to `botright`? I like the idea of keeping `vertical` as a quick alias for a vertical split, using `split` for more granular control, and dropping `belowright`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3195,6 +3212,11 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
                   • fixed: If true when anchor is NW or SW, the float window
                     would be kept fixed even if the window would be truncated.
                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body:
Working on this now, and I'm realizing that the behavior of the options that match `parse_cmd` is not the same as my current implementation. The current implementation allows splitting any direction from any window, but `:belowright` / `:topleft` always create top-level splits. Imo the current functionality of this PR is more predictable and flexible than this would be. Should I use the names of the `split` options but keep the current functionality? 

I think a good enum option for the current implementation would be `top`/`bottom`/`left`/`right` because that more accurately describes how the window will split. 

| split | win | resulting action |
|--------|-------|------------------------|
| top   | 0     | horizontal split above curwin |
| left   | nil   | top-level left-aligned vert split |
| right | 1002 | vertical split to the right of window 1002 |

etc...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -3195,6 +3212,11 @@ nvim_open_win({buffer}, {enter}, {*config})                  *nvim_open_win()*
                   • fixed: If true when anchor is NW or SW, the float window
                     would be kept fixed even if the window would be truncated.
                   • hide: If true the floating window will be hidden.
+                  • vertical: If creating a normal (split) window, split
+                    vertically.
+                  • belowright: If creating a normal window, split to the

comment_data.body: Makes sense. Though should the "top" case in your table be named "above"? Compare the `:aboveleft` command to the `:topleft` command.

comment_data.body:
Maybe `win_get_config` shouldn't return anything for `relative` in split wins then? Currently it returns an empty string.

Edit: Tried this, it breaks a lot of plugins. Maybe `win_get_config` shouldn't be changed? Or should we just make plugins adapt to the change?


comment_data.body: I would drop the "can" from these test names and just use `'creates a split window'`.
Will do, thanks for the reviews!
Todo: fix this (accidentally replaced)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -564,7 +564,7 @@ describe('API/win', function()
 
     it('closing current (float) window of another tabpage #15313', function()
       command('tabedit')
-      command('botright split')
+      command('belowright split')

comment_regular_data.body: Seems to be working well, and I cleaned up formatting as much as I could without going line-by-line through the diffs :)

Found an issue: When opening a split in a non-current tabpage, the win does not appear to be valid (fails on `win_config.c:266`), but it is usable and visible in the tabpage. Will add a test for this and try to figure it out.

This is The Way! This was always the intention for `nvim_open_win`. 

Obligatory mantra: one interface (`nvim_open_win`) is usually better than multiple separate interfaces (e.g. `nvim_open_float` + `nvim_open_split`) unless there is truly an "impedance mismatch" that justifies separate interfaces. One interface tends to result in less documentation (redundant documentation is a burden on both users _and_ maintainers) and less code.

> This is The Way! This was always the intention for `nvim_open_win`.
>
> Obligatory mantra: one interface (`nvim_open_win`) is usually better than multiple separate interfaces (e.g. `nvim_open_float` + `nvim_open_split`) unless there is truly an "impedance mismatch" that justifies separate interfaces. One interface tends to result in less documentation (redundant documentation is a burden on both users _and_ maintainers) and less code.

Awesome! Glad this was the plan already, I just stumbled on the issue and thought it would be cool to have (and an interesting challenge). I definitely agree that a unified interface is best, especially for UI-related features that will often be customized by users.

There's also *tons* of this type of thing used in plugins (and in my [`tabpage_set_layout`](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/24507) implementation) that will be able to be replaced, it will be very nice to have a single way to open all kinds of windows:

```lua
local splitright = vim.o.splitright
local splitbelow = vim.o.splitbelow
vim.o.splitright = true
vim.o.splitbelow = true
vim.api.nvim_win_call(win, vim.cmd.vsplit)
vim.o.splitright = splitright
vim.o.splitbelow = splitbelow
```

>  Should `width` / `height` FloatConfig props apply to splits now?

yes and it should perhaps be renamed to `WinConfig`.

> Should `win->w_float_config` be cleared when a floating window is moved to a split?

yes

> > Should `width` / `height` FloatConfig props apply to splits now?
> 
> yes and it should perhaps be renamed to `WinConfig`.

I considered that, I think that makes more sense at this point, but didn't want to make large changes like that without checking first. Maybe it would be good to add the `vertical` (or `split`) props to `win_get_config` as well?

> > Should `win->w_float_config` be cleared when a floating window is moved to a split?
> 
> yes

Sounds good, I'm currently setting it to the newly parsed config (as `win_new_float` does), so I think that's the current behavior.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(api): make nvim_open_win support normal (non-floating) windows
